titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Richard St. John Papers, 1972-2020 SC.2020.03
titlestmt.author: Brianna Facciani.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-01-25 11:08:31 -0500.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: Richard St. John is a published writer of three collections of poetry, titled The Pure Inconstancy of Grace (2005), Each Perfected Name (2015),Book of Entangled Souls (2020), and one chapbook, titled Shrine (2011). The St. John Papers include drafts, manuscripts, newspaper clippings, photographs, audio material, and copies of his published works (with the exception of Book of Entagled Souls), including periodicals in which St. John's poetry has been featured.

acqinfo.head: Acqusition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Richard St. John on June 25, 2020.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into 9 series:
I. The Pure Inconstancy of Grace
VI. John the Baptist Series of Poems
V. Poetry experiments: inspired by current news and events

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Born in 1952 in Columbus, Ohio, Richard St. John is a poet and the author of two published volumes of poetry, titled The Pure Inconstancy of Grace (2005) and Each Perfected Name (2015), and one chapbook, titled Shrine (2011). St. John and his family moved to suburban Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, in 1955. Under the influence of a gifted middle and high school teacher, St. John became interested in poetry and, by the time of his 1970 graduation from high school, he was fully committed to becoming a poet. He attended Princeton University, graduating summa cum laude with a B.A. in English in 1974, and then went to the University of Virginia for his M.A. in English in 1975. It was during this time at U.VA that he became engaged to his longtime friend, Katherine "Kate" Mitchell, and after completing his degree, they married.

St. John considered teaching as a career, but following his graduation from college, he accepted a position at a Pittsburgh advertising agency, Creamer FSR, where he worked for four years. Wanting to commit himself to poetry more, he entered the nonprofit sector in 1981 and secured a half-time writing position with the Allegheny Conference on Community Development. In 1982, he accepted a full-time position at the Conference with a mix of writing and program responsibilities, including work in the organization's new program area of neighborhood development.

From 1984 through 1990, he worked with Oakland Planning and Development Corporation (OPDC) as Associate Director and then as Executive Director. While at OPDC, he completed a National Internship in Community Development through the Development Training Institute headquartered in Baltimore, Maryland. He continued working in neighborhood development as a real estate development consultant to a tenants' organization and subsequently, from 1992 to 2001, as Executive Director for the Community Design Center of Pittsburgh. Throughout this period, he also was active with a variety of nonprofit boards, commissions, and coalitions, including the Mayor's Zoning Advisory Group (as co-chair), Sustainable Pittsburgh, the Community Technical Assistance Center, the Working Group on Community Development, and others.

In the mid-1990s, in the hope of having a collection published, St. John began sending his book-length poetry manuscripts to publishers while continuing to work in the nonprofit sector. In 2001, St. John left the Community Design Center of Pittsburgh and accepted a mid-career Loeb Fellowship for independent study at Harvard University. Returning to Pittsburgh in 2002, he raised funds and initiated Conversations for Common Wealth (CCW), a program which used poetry and other materials to help diverse groups reflect on the ethical callings in their lives. He also assisted the Community House Literacy Center and Community House Presbyterian Church with various projects, including renovation of new space for both organizations.

In 2004, one of his manuscripts was selected as first runner-up for the T.S. Eliot Prize for Poetry, and one year later, Truman State University Press published that collection as The Pure Inconstancy of Grace. In 2007, at the conclusion of both CCW and Community House projects, he became Executive Director of Autumn House Press in Pittsburgh, a nationally respected nonprofit publisher of poetry, fiction and creative non-fiction. St. John left Autumn House Press to pursue conversations-related partnerships in 2011 and subsequently accepted a position as Executive Director for the Squirrel Hill Urban Coalition, retiring from that position in late 2014.

In the same decade, Finishing Line Press published his long poem as a chapbook, titled Shrine (2011), and Truman State University Press published his second full-length collection, titled Each Perfected Name (2015). Throughout his writing career, St. John was published in numerous newspapers and literary journals, such as The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, Pittsburgh City Paper, Carolina Quarterly, Sewanee Review, and The Fourth River. In addition, St. John has read his poetry at numerous cafés, universities, and events. St. John still continues to write and has completed a third full-length collection of poetry with the working title Book of Entangled Souls, which is scheduled for publication by Broadstone Books in 2022.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright is still held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Richard St. John Papers, 1972-2019, SC.2020.03, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The St. John Papers contain written or typed drafts and manuscripts of St. John's poetry from the early 1970s to 2020, as well as correspondence, newspaper clippings, advertisements, books, and literary journals associated with St. John's poems. The collection includes multiple draft versions of the poems in St. John's three published volumes in addition to many drafts and largely unpublished works of poetry created throughout the decades. The correspondence highlights some conversations with other authors, editors, and friends about St. John's poetry. Photographs of St. John's trip to Walden Pond in Massachusetts are also available along with an audio recording of a radio show's poetry reading.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Lawrence Lee Papers, 1920-1978, SC.1978.01, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System
Gerald Stern Papers, 1920-2012, SC.2007.04, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System
Liane Ellison Norman Papers, 1955-2008, AIS.2010.02, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Brianna Facciani in February 2021.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains the published copy and drafts of St. John's collection of poetry, The Pure Inconstancy of Grace. Oversized materials that appear in this series can be found in Oversize 5.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains a group of unpublished poems known as the "John the Baptist Series."

did.unittitle: "John the Baptist Series Draft with Preface"
Poetry experiments: inspired by current news and events

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes poetry drafts that all have newspaper clippings attached to them that relate to or are the inspiration for the subsequent poem.

did.unittitle: "New Bishop Faces Challenge of Shrinking Priesthood"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes poetry drafts of "unrhymed sonnets," as described by St. John.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes drafts, revisions, and notes related to the poetry that Richard St. John composed over a fifty-year time period. These drafts, referred to by the author as "discarded materials," are unpublished.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains early content and writings from St. John's time as an undergraduate student at Princeton and graduate student at the University of Virginia, including junior and senior theses, literary magazine publications, and collections of poetry. It also contains more drafts of poetry after his collegiate years. Some of the dates range to years outside of the 70s due to the author's later revision of the poems. Oversized materials that appear in this series can be found in Oversize 5. These drafts, referred to by the author as "discarded materials," are unpublished.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains drafts of poetry dated in the 1980s. Some of the dates range to years outside of the 80s due to the author's later revision of the poems. These drafts, referred to by the author as "discarded materials," are unpublished.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains drafts of poetry, along with poetry advertisements. Some of the dates range to years outside of the 90s due to the author's later revision of the poems. These drafts, referred to by the author as "discarded materials," are unpublished.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains poetry drafts and email correspondences during the 2000s. Additionally, St. John's writing planner and poetry reading advertisements from this decade can also be found within the subseries. Some of the dates range to years outside of the 2000s due to the author's later revision of the poems. Oversized materials that appear in this series can be found in Oversize 5. These drafts, referred to by the author as "discarded materials," are unpublished.

scopecontent.p: This series contains St. John's published works featured in newspapers and literary magazines. Oversized materials that appear in this series can be found in Oversize 5.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series includes photography of St. John's trip to Walden Pond in Massachusetts along with a cassette tape recording of St. John at a radio station poetry reading.
